+JAMESGHOST While I agree that it was probably not the creator's intent to 
make a social comment on the issues I stated above, they engaged in 
narrative and character tropes which are problematic in nature. So even if 
the creators do not personally hold homophobic or transphobic views, they 
used homophobia and transphobia to tell their story. Considering how well 
funded and public Tropfest is, it is upsetting and insensitive at the very 
least that this film won, and its creators win a significant reward.

While I agree that media should provoke discussion, it does not mean that 
its creators and those who publicise it are unaccountable for problematic 
elements in their work. It is through media that discrimination and 
prejudice is normalised and maintained. And so I am of the opinion that one 
should always call out problematic elements in media, no matter how 
seemingly benign.

+K R I still feel this film short fosters or continues the misconceptions 
concerning trans-gendered and/or gay/lesbian  individuals, Is it necessary 
to "shame" people? The wife comes off as a real bitch and this says to the 
world it is OK to bully/insult/shame/hurt people on a grand scale. None of 
these characters reflect anything positive toward the LGBTQ community.

Being disgusted by the behavior at the end was what the audience was meant 
to feel. You see throughout the beginning, the film builds trust between 
the main character and 'Harry' and he eventually reaches an understanding 
and acceptance of trans people. But wait, near the end you see him just 
about to reject his own closeted emotions and shut out Harry from his life 
in a form of hypocrisy and ignorance, hurting Harry's feelings. And then, 
the tables turn and Peter gets shamed for his own inclinations, which in a 
way, subjects him to the same irrational guilt and humiliation for who he 
is that he was just about to project on someone else. Most non-cis people 
lack the sentiment that they are normal, but instead have their genuine 
feelings be taken lightly in media and in the company of others. The film 
shows how cruel it can be from both sides.

Not every film addressing transphobia/homophobia must make a relationship 
seem like a fairytale land in a typical romcom plot. This short was a 
strategic play on reality, which in my opinion, makes it deserving of its 
award.

I believe that we can be indignant about more than one thing; we are 
capable of caring about multiple things at the same time. People can just 
the same care about misrepresentation or trivialisation of LGBTIQ issues in 
western media, as well as the various injustices that the community faces 
abroad as well (both are worthwhile causes in different senses. Attention 
does not need to be sacrificed for one in order to deal with the other). 
There will always be the group of people complaining about the people 
complaining; I don't believe that these complaints will sway people into 
starting to undermine our 'legitimate' grievances' (I believe that you're 
referring to issues dealing with violence, employment, etc?). It's nice to 
be able to address topics like this in a public forum though; regardless of 
whether or not people perceive it to be a product of overreactions. I think 
it shows how far we've come that our cisgendered, straight allies are aware 
of some of the problematic aspects of this film, and willing to point them 
out.

I'm not sure if it's due to my poor understanding of context clues, but I 
thought the gist of your original comment was "why are you complaining 
about this, people have far worse problems in Muslim/African countries". 
Which aside from being a fallacy of relative privation, seemed to 
trivialise the problems of LGBTIQ people in first world countries?

+Ludicrously Idiotic Why do you feel that my comment invalidated your 
experiences of being oppressed? Nowhere did I tell anyone to "suck it up". 
On the contrary, my intention was to urge people to save their indignation 
for more worthwhile causes. I would argue that it is the "understandable" 
reaction to this film that invalidates and trivializes our experiences of 
homophobic oppression. Most people will see this "lashing out" as 
hysterical and ridiculous, and the danger is that that will extend to our 
legitimate grievances as well.

I apologise if I came across as aggressive to you, and thank you for 
correcting my spelling mistake (English is not my first language). I guess 
that as some one who may not have been 'brutally oppressed', I felt that 
your comment invalidated my experiences of being oppressed. As part of a 
minority group, I guess it gets tiring to be told to suck it up, other 
people are more oppressed than you are, so you should be happy with what 
you have and not ask for more. This was more me lashing out against the 
accumulation of these experiences, rather than your comment alone. In that 
same vein, the lashing out at this clip by the LGBTIQ community can be seen 
as a response of a cumulation of comedic media where their sexuality/gender 
identity is the punchline, rather than the film as a singular entity. I do 
agree that some reactions seem disproportionate, but at the same time it's 
understandable.

And do you feel that you've addressed my comment in any meaningful way, 
other than to say it was not "conductive"? (I think you meant conducive.) 
My point was that privileged gays and lesbians in the West are often quick 
to get their knickers in a knot over something as trivial as a comedic 
short film, but have nothing to say at all about the brutal oppression of 
their fellow homosexuals in non-Western cultures. In order to solve a 
problem, however nuanced, one must first identify it.

It's pretty clear - especially the first part where the Helen/Harry 
character describes their transition experience. 

Perhaps if you've never experienced marginalisation, stigma or abuse 
because of your gender identity or sexuality then the blatant homophobia 
and transphobia in this film would fly over your head. Look closer.

The first few minutes the 'Harry/Helen' character describes the process of 
transitioning and coming to terms with their gender identity as an 
apparently flippant, easy and trivial decision - on par with getting a nose 
job. It trivialises the stigma and psychological trauma that many trans 
people go through by assuming it to be an easy experience. 

Second, it insinuates that because 'Harry/Helen' is (supposedly) a 
female-to-male transsexual, that he is not a 'real' man, therefore it's not 
'gay' to sleep with him. When it's revealed that he's not actually who he 
said he was, it's insinuated that the main character has been tricked into 
having gay sex. Perpetuating stereotypes of gay men as predatory, and of 
transgendered identity as being 'less than'. 

I get that the director wanted to make a comment about how the media can be 
manipulative and immoral - but he seriously went about it in the wrong way. 
There's nothing 'edgy' or subversive about further perpetuating harmful 
stereotypes about marginalised communities.

So, how many of the so called offended people are actually transgendered 
and how many are just jumping on the bandwagon?

I am transgendered. I transitioned from the female body I was born in to 
live as a man when I was 19 years old. I am now 34.

I am not offended by this film. It does not:
(a) make fun of transgender people
(b) proclaim that transgender people are to be feared or hated.

Yes, the "Harry" character is flippant in his description of his 
transition. But this is a 7 minute fiction film, not a documentary 
purporting to tell the story of the transgender journey. I myself have had 
similarly flippant conversations about my transition in contexts where I 
didn't want to get too involved in a D&M.

Yes, the "Harry" character tricks the other guy into sleeping with him. But 
the encounter is still consensual because it is the "Harry" character that 
the other guy is attracted to. It's no really any different to getting 
drunk and sleeping with someone you found unattractive while sober and then 
having the morning after shame (regardless of whether you slept with a man 
or a woman).

The film itself makes three points:
(a) there are people out there who are really vindictive who will hold 
grudges for a long time
(b) there is a perception that the television industry might stop at 
nothing to create new shows that exploit people
(c) we as a society would probably watch a show like Bamboozled and what 
does that say about us.

If a show is transphobic merely because it shows a character who purports 
to be transgendered in a poor light, then surely:
(a) any movie that shows a male villain is sexist against men (this would 
include every Marvel comic that's been made into a movie because they 
almost always have male villains)
(b) any movie that shows a female behaving badly is sexist against women 
(this probably includes a huge list of movies too)
(c) any comedy is anti-human because all comedy will poke fun at someone.

This means that, by extension, we should boycott all films. And, while 
we're at it, let's boycott all books that also fall into those categories.

I think it's sad that the thought police are using transphobia to attack 
this film. There is real transphobia happening out there every day. Real 
violence. Real families rejecting their children. Real employers refusing 
people jobs. This film in no way creates or adds to that real transphobia.﻿

i was seriously bullied in high school, to the point where i still suffer,

certainly, though, we need to be able to teach ourselves how to be stronger

you can distance yourself from their paradigm. if you can, walk away, don't 
get drawn in. you can say, that is their issue, not mine. don't buy into 
hate. acknowledging it can give it power. ignore it as much as possible. 
reacting can make a situation worse. obviously there is a time for self 
defense. i went through hell at school, but if i reacted, perhaps it 
would've been even worse (although, it was bad enough!). and i had noone to 
teach me how to self defend when things got physical. 

anyway, i really don't think this film was being, at least consciously, 
bigoted. i don't believe it had that sinister agenda. if anything, it could 
maybe be called juvenile, but not bigoted. and sometimes juvenile things 
are funny, i mean, come on, don't lose all your child like perceptions.

another important thing to mention is that sometimes people who are phobic, 
can change their minds some day, given the chance. but it seems some of you 
would lock them away and throw away the key, and fail to realise this 
fundamental part of the human condition. that we can learn. but it needs to 
be in a positive environment. keep doing what you're doing, be a good 
person, and you never know, you may show someone that it's ok to be you. 
don't force issues on people, it could back fire. allow people their own 
time to work things out. keep in mind, that sometimes (not always!) a lot 
of homophobic people are actually gay. and all these types of people 
suppress their true selves due to their own particular environmental 
causes. sometimes those causes are too deep to ever be altered.

we need to laugh at ourselves sometimes, too. look at the classic series 
acropolis now. we greeks poked fun at ourselves at a time when there was 
lots of racism against us. it had a hugely positive effect on this culture 
and more importantly, on ourselves. when people see that you don't take 
yourself too seriously, their hatred or preconceptions or phobias, 
intriguingly, dissolve. it's a very interesting phenomena we should take 
into consideration here.

don't make yourself out to be a victim. this reality will stick to you like
